doc.title: Sika: Scenario analysis shows limited risk to mid-term guidance
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Sika Scenario analysis shows limited risk to mid-term guidanceSika Scenario analysis shows limited risk to mid-term guid_2025-08-29

passages.text: European Construction & Building Materials

Sika has fallen from grace over the last few years, leading to a significant derating, driven by negative perception of the MBCC acquisition, slowdown in bolt-on acquisition activity as well as underlying softness in most major markets. The primary question on investors' minds is when will Sika get back to mid-single digit organic growth. Here we seek the answer to this question through several scenarios. We also update our model post Q2 results.

**Model update:** We update our model post Q2 results to reflect updated guidance and recent market trends. We have toned down our volume numbers given the US has weakened vs the start of the year and the European recovery is getting delayed. We have also slightly reduced the pricing in APAC, as Sika is seeing significant deflationary pressures in China. We have also reflected the sizable FX moves in Q2. As a result of these changes, we lower overall and local currency (LC) revenue growth rates by ~9% and 2% for FY25 and ~3% and 1% in FY26, and our price target from CHF 285/share to CHF 255/share.

**Scenario analysis**: We analyzed scenarios with different assumptions for underlying market volumes/activity as well as Sika's bolt-on acquisition activity. A permanent 1% uplift/decline in all underlying market volumes relative to our base case over FY26-28 results in CHF 20/share change to our valuation. In our model, we do not assume any future M&A beyond what Sika have already announced. If we assume 1 further acquisition in Q4'25, 4 bolt-ons in 2026 and 6 bolt-ons in 2027-28, the valuation potentially increases by CHF 20-25/share.

**When does Sika get back to ~6% organic growth?** In our updated base case, Sika reaches 6% organic growth by 2027 (vs by 2026 in our previous model). With 1% higher volumes, this is reached by 2026 and with 1% lower volumes, Sika just falls short of the 6% even in 2028. **We do not believe Sika's mid-term LC growth guidance of 6-9% is at risk.** Even without future M&A, LC growth reaches 6-7% in 2027-28. Assuming future potential bolt-ons results in 6-10% LC growth over 2026-28 (see Exhibit 13).

Sika remains our top pick as their innovative and differentiated products gives them high pricing power, allows them to consistently grow their addressable market and capture higher market share. The short term weakness provides an attractive entry point, however, management have to deliver on their guidance, ramp-up bolt-ons and demonstrate Sika's continued ability to grow above markets. We rate Sika OP with a PT of CHF 255/share.

First Published: 29 Aug 2025 05:00 UTC Completion Date: 28 Aug 2025 16:22 UTC
Pujarini Ghosh, CFA +44 207 676 6807
**Specialist Sales**

Sika, once a favorite of investors, has fallen from grace over the last couple of years. This was due to several reasons, most of which were in some way related to the MBCC acquisition. The large acquisition wasn't well appreciated by the market due to:

- Question on whether the price paid was too high as MBCC had to sell some assets ahead of the transaction due to competition/anti-trust reasons.- Synergy guidance was too low to begin with, and some investors did not want to wait 3-4 years to see the synergies materialise.- Management focus on the MBCC integration over the last couple of years as well as the high leverage post the acquisition meant that bolt-on acquisition activity was muted (which investors do appreciate).
One unrelated reason is the underlying market weakness (see Exhibit 1):

- European markets have been extremely weak for the last couple of years, and while we have seen some green shoots with improving consumer sentiment especially related to the German stimulus announcement and an increasing expectation of a ceasefire in Ukraine, the recovery seems to be longer than expected.- The US market has also been subdued over the last couple of years, but hopes were sparked by a strong start to this year (in Jan and Feb), however, this was short-lived as tariff uncertainties (since Mar) made the market soft, which has continued into Q2 and Q3. Once the tariffs/trade agreements are finalized we could see some rebound especially in the commercial end-markets, however, the residential market is expected to continue to be subdued unless rates come down. The increasing expectation of the Fed cutting rates is providing some relief to the construction market.- The Chinese market continues to be a pain-point for Sika as it continues to be under pricing pressure and volumes remain weak with expectations of a recovery looking bleak.
EXHIBIT 1: Where different markets are on the construction cycle

While Sika continued to outperform peers and the underlying construction markets, the weak underlying markets have meant that Sika has not been able to get back to the \(\sim 6\%\) organic growth range that they have maintained over the last 20 years.
EXHIBIT 2: Sika has grown 6-7% organically over past 20 years complimented by inorganic growth
Source: Sika, Bernstein analysis

This had led to significant derating of the stock over the last couple of years which accelerated since Q4'24. Since Oct'24, the stock has derated 6 turns from over 20x to \(\sim 15x\) EV/EBITDA at present (see Exhibit 3).
EXHIBIT 3: 4. Since Oct'24, the stock has derated 6 turns from over 20x to \(\sim 15x\) EV/EBITDA
Sika 1yr fwd EV/EBITDA
Source: Bloomberg, Bernstein analysis

The primary question on investors' minds is when will Sika return to the mid- single digit local organic growth. Following the guidance cut for FY25, a related question is whether Sika's medium term growth ambition of 6- 9% in local currency at risk?
These are the main questions that we delve into and try to answer through a few scenarios.
Before going into the alternative scenarios, we highlight our base case and highlight our model update post the H1 results.
We reflected the H1 actuals and updated guidance in our Sika model. The main changes were:

- Americas: After a strong start to the year, Americas volumes declined from March onward driven by the uncertainty created around tariffs. This had the biggest impact on US volumes, but Canada and Latin American volumes also suffered. So we have toned down our estimates for the Americas. In our base case model, we have reduced our volume assumption for the Americas to \(0.2\%\) from \(3\%\) previously for FY25. In our updated model, the entire Americas volume growth is coming from the underlying market, whereas previously we had assumed that \(2\%\) was coming from underlying volume growth and \(1\%\) from market expansion and Sika's market share gains. For FY26, we have reduced our volume assumption from \(4.5\%\) to \(3.1\%\) (of which \(\sim 1.4\%\) is coming from market expansion and market share gains vs \(1.75\%\) previously). We have left the volume assumption in FY27 and FY28 roughly unchanged at \(\sim 4.5\%\) and \(\sim 6\%\) (of which \(\sim 2.25\%\) and \(2.5\%\) resp. comes from market expansion and market share gains).

- Europe: While Europe is recovering, management highlighted in the H1 results call that the improvements are coming in small steps suggesting a weaker or delayed recovery than previously expected. As a result, we have cut our estimates for EMEA. In our base case model, we have reduced our volume assumption for EMEA to \(1.2\%\) from \(2.2\%\) previously for FY25. In our updated model, the entire EMEA volume growth is coming from the underlying market, whereas previously we had assumed that \(0.5\%\) from market expansion and Sika's market share gains. For FY26, we have reduced our volume assumption from \(5\%\) to \(4.5\%\) (of which \(\sim 1.1\%\) is coming from market expansion and market share gains vs \(1.4\%\) previously). We have left the volume assumption in FY27 and FY28 roughly unchanged at \(\sim 5\%\) and \(\sim 3\%\) (of which \(\sim 1.6\%\) and \(2.5\%\) resp. comes from market expansion and market share gains).

- APAC: The APAC H1 volume growth was well below our previous expectations given the continued weakness in China. China, which accounts for around half of the region's sales, continues to be difficult, pushing back the recovery of the region, while other markets are showing positive trends led by India and Southeast Asia. We have slightly reduced our volume forecast for APAC for H2. Overall, we have reduced our volume assumption for APAC to \(-0.4\%\) from \(2\%\) previously for FY25. In our updated model, the entire APAC volume growth is coming from the underlying market, whereas previously we had assumed that \(0.9\%\) was coming from underlying volume growth and \(1\%\) from market expansion and Sika's market share gains. For FY26, we have reduced our volume assumption from \(3.8\%\) to \(3.4\%\) (of which \(\sim 1.4\%\) is coming from market expansion and market share gains vs \(1.75\%\) previously). We have left the volume assumption in FY27 and FY28 roughly unchanged at \(\sim 4.5\%\) and \(\sim 6\%\) (of which \(\sim 2.75\%\) and \(3.75\%\) resp. comes from market expansion and market share gains).
- Americas: We have marginally reduced the pricing in Americas in FY25 from \(1.1\%\) to \(1\%\) and left them unchanged at \(1.5\%\) in FY26 and FY27 and \(2\%\) in FY28.
- Europe: We have left pricing assumptions unchanged for EMEA.

- APAC: Management highlighted on the H1 results call that they are seeing deflationary pressures in China. They also mentioned that in H1 overall pricing was \(\sim 0.3\%\) and ex. China the pricing was \(\sim 0.5\%\) . For FY25 the pricing expectation is \(1\%\) ex China and \(\sim 0.6\%\) overall. We have reduced pricing for the APAC region by \(1\%\) from \(0.4\%\) to \(-0.6\%\) for FY25.
FX: We have incorporated the latest FX rates which have moved strongly in Q2.

Personnel cost modeling: We tweaked the modeling of personnel costs to segregate the overall increase into underlying wage inflation and the FX/mix impact. For example in H1 underlying wage inflation was \(\sim 3.5\%\) , however, there was a decline in the overall personnel costs driven by an FX/mix impact. Sika saw more expansion in MEA, LatAm, Asia, India where wages are lower, so mix effect of expansion in lower cost countries worked in Sika's favour.

Other segments and activities: We have tweaked the overheads down from \(1.3\%\) of sales to \(1.1\%\) of sales for FY25 as it is expected to normalize after being quite high the last couple of years post the MBCC acquisition.

As a result of these changes, we have now lowered our Sika price target to CHF 255/share (from CHF 285/share previously or \(\sim 11\%\) reduction), implying \(36\%\) potential upside to the current market price. Our overall local currency revenue growth (2025- 28 average) has reduced from \(5.9\%\) to \(5.2\%\) which is primarily driven by the reduction in volume growth from \(4.2\%\) to \(3.5\%\) . We now get to \(\sim 6\%\) organic growth by 2027 rather than 2026 in our previous model (see Exhibit 4). We have not baked in any future M&A beyond those which have been already announced by the company (as a result, local currency and organic growth are the same 2026 onward). EBITDA margin for 2025 has shifted down from \(19.8\%\) in our previous model to \(19.6\%\) (within the margin guidance range of \(19.5 - 19.8\%\) ). For FY26, we forecast EBITDA margin of \(20.4\%\) vs management guidance of margins exceeding \(20\%\) by 2026 once MBCC synergies are fully realized, and we forecast EBITDA margin reaching \(22.2\%\) by 2028 vs mid-term guidance of \(20 - 23\%\) (see Exhibit 5).
EXHIBIT 4: We have lowered overall topline growth rates for Sika primarily for FY25 and FY26 and this has been driven largely by weaker volumes and currency translation
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates
EXHIBIT 5: We have reduced our estimates for Sika by \(8 - 15\%\) over 2025-28
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates

We have analyzed several scenarios with different assumption on underlying market volumes/activity as well as Sika's bolt-on acquisition activity. In our base, bear and bull scenarios, we have only changed volume assumptions. In our base case, we have not included any potential future M&A over and above what has already been announced. If we juxtapose these scenarios with higher acquisition activity, we get another dimension regarding the growth rates and valuation of Sika.

In the base case scenario which is our published case, we are assuming a gradual recovery in Europe, the Americas see slight growth in 2025 followed by a recovery from 2026 and APAC sees slight volume decline in 2025 followed by a recovery in 2026.

In the Americas, the base case anticipates that the US will benefit from IIJA funds entering the construction phase over the coming years. Growth will be driven by reshoring activities, with a strong recovery expected once tariff uncertainties are resolved starting in early 2026. Investments in data centers continues to contribute to robust growth. Canada and Latin America (LATAM) is similarly expected to experience solid growth following the resolution of tariff uncertainties.

In Europe, the German stimulus has been a key driver, and we expect funding to begin flowing into renovation projects by the end of this year, with larger new- build projects receiving investment starting next year. Additionally, the EU's roll- out of the Green Deal will support low- carbon construction, which will benefit Sika's solutions.

In the APAC region, China is expected to demonstrate positive growth over the medium term, driven by a shift toward higher- quality construction, electrification, and stronger capabilities among main contractors aiming to compete globally and improve efficiency, areas where Sika is actively involved. Outside of China, the region is forecasted to see low single- digit positive growth, led by India, Southeast Asia, and the Automotive & Industry sectors.
Our base case valuation is CHF 255/share.
Underlying volume assumptions in our base case in shown in Exhibit 6.
EXHIBIT 6: Underlying volume assumptions in our base case
Sika volume forecastsFY25FY26FY27FY28Base caseEMEA1.2%4.5%5.2%3.3%Americas0.2%3.1%4.6%6.1%APAC-0.4%3.3%4.4%6.2%Group average incl. market expansion0.5%3.8%4.8%4.9%
Source: Bernstein analysis
In the bear case, we assume a permanent \(1\%\) decline in all underlying market volumes relative to our base case over FY26- 28.

For Americas, while Sika anticipates a strong recovery in the US driven by progress in infrastructure projects and a rebound in project activity starting in the second half of this year, our bear case assumes a slower recovery due to ongoing tariff uncertainties. We expect inflation to stay elevated because of increased tariffs and foreseen significant reductions in interest rates, which will dampen purchasing power and keep residential demand subdued. Additionally, commercial activity is projected to be negatively affected by high tariffs, slowing economic growth, and elevated interest rates, which will constrain business investments. Canada and LATAM are expected to be affected by elevated tariffs alongside a slowdown in economic growth, which will negatively influence construction activities in these regions. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of \(2.6\%\) in 2025, \(2.7\%\) in 2026, \(4.1\%\) in 2027, and \(6.6\%\) in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of \(2.9\%\) in 2025, \(4.7\%\) in 2026, \(6.1\%\) in 2027, and \(8.6\%\) in 2028.

For Europe, we expect the Russian- Ukraine conflict to persist and escalate, which will likely postpone the anticipated reconstruction efforts in Ukraine. While Sika foresees the German stimulus package as a positive catalyst with funds beginning to be released by the end of this year, we assume bureaucratic hurdles will slow down the process, and the stimulus will not significantly boost infrastructure development. Additionally, we anticipate delays in investments related to the EU Green Deal projects, which will negatively affect the growth prospects for Sika's low- carbon construction products. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of \(2.6\%\) in 2025, \(5.1\%\) in 2026, \(5.8\%\) in 2027, and \(3.7\%\) in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of \(2.7\%\) in 2025, \(6.1\%\) in 2026, \(6.8\%\) in 2027, and \(4.7\%\) in 2028.

In the APAC region, we expect tariffs to significantly affect countries such as China, India, Japan, and Australia, leading to a slowdown in economic activity. We assume the anticipated medium- term recovery in China does not materialize, with the property sector slowdown persisting across the region. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of \(- 0.1\%\) in 2025, \(3.9\%\) in 2026, \(4.9\%\) in 2027, and \(7.0\%\) in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of \(0.0\%\) in 2025, \(4.9\%\) in 2026, \(5.9\%\) in 2027, and \(8.0\%\) in 2028.
Underlying volume assumptions in our bear case in shown in Exhibit 7.
EXHIBIT 7: Underlying volume assumptions in our bear case
Sika volume forecastsFY25FY26FY27FY28Bear caseEMEA1.5%3.5%4.2%2.5%Americas0.6%2.1%3.6%5.1%APAC4.7%2.3%3.4%5.2%Group average incl. market expansion1.9%2.8%3.8%4.0%
Source: Bernstein analysis
In the bull case, we assume a 1% consistent increase in all underlying market volumes compared to our base case over FY26-28.

In the Americas, the US is expected to avoid any negative effects from tariff-related uncertainties and structural tailwinds from reshoring activities (boosted by tariffs on imports), and housing shortage, repair and maintenance cycle materialise. The Fed cuts interest rates which improves affordability and provides an uplift to the residential and commercial end-markets. Infrastructure spending accelerates with progress on the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) as well as upcoming future Highway Bills, with substantial investments planned over the coming years. Canada and Latin America are also not materially affected by tariffs, as they reach agreements with the US, and inflation should remain stable in these regions. Latin America is poised for robust growth, driven by infrastructure projects and rapid urbanization. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of 3.1% in 2025, 5.7% in 2026, 7.1% in 2027, and 9.6% in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of 2.9% in 2025, 4.7% in 2026, 6.1% in 2027, and 8.6% in 2028.

For Europe, we expect Russian-Ukraine war to end quickly, which will not only improve the sentiments but also makes way for reconstruction efforts in Ukraine. German stimulus to provide significant boost to the construction activities of the country, while France is projected to recover and experience positive volume growth. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of 2.9% in 2025, 7.1% in 2026, 7.8% in 2027, and 5.7% in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of 2.7% in 2025, 6.1% in 2026, 6.8% in 2027, and 4.7% in 2028.

In the APAC region, tariffs are expected to have minimal impact. Construction activity in China is projected to rebound, resulting in positive growth over the medium term. Meanwhile, other areas outside of China are anticipated to experience strong growth across all segments. Based on these assumptions, we project local currency growth of 0.1% in 2025, 6.4% in 2026, 7.4% in 2027, and 9.5% in 2028, compared to our base case estimates of 0.0% in 2025, 4.9% in 2026, 5.9% in 2027, and 8.0% in 2028.
Underlying volume assumptions in our bull case in shown in Exhibit 8.
EXHIBIT 8: Underlying volume assumptions in our bull case
Sika volume forecastsFY25FY26FY27FY28Bull caseEMEA1.3%5.5%6.2%4.5%Americas0.4%4.1%5.6%7.1%APAC-0.2%4.3%5.4%7.2%Group average incl. market expansion0.6%4.8%5.8%6.0%
Source: Bernstein analysis
In Exhibit 9 to Exhibit 12, we show the local currency growth by region and for the group under the different scenarios.
EXHIBIT 9: Americas local currency growth under base, bull and bear scenarios
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates
EXHIBIT 10: EMEA local currency growth under base, bull and bear scenarios
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates
EXHIBIT 11: APAC local currency growth under base, bull and bear scenarios
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates
EXHIBIT 12: Sika Group local currency growth under base, bull and bear scenarios
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates

Sika is getting back on the bolt- on machine. Investors appreciate bolt- ons because synergy materialization is relatively quick. These are small, often family owned businesses, which do not have the technical know- how or the scale of Sika and as a result, Sika can introduce these to the acquired companies resulting in immediate margin expansion.

Over the last couple of years, since the MBCC acquisition in late 2022, management was focused on the MBCC integration and the leverage was also quite high. As a result, the bolt- on M&A activity was quite low. Now, bolt- on acquisition activity is picking up again, because the MBCC acquisition is now almost done and leverage is under control. This year Sika have already announced 4 relatively small acquisitions, which is driving \(\sim 1.1\%\) of local currency growth for FY25.

In our base case, we have not baked in any further acquisitions over the forecast period. In our scenario with potential future acquisitions, we assume 1 further acquisition in Q4'25, 4 bolt- ons in 2026 and 6 bolt- ons in 2027 and 2028. The average size of these acquisitions is assumed to be \(\sim\) 50mn of annual revenues, and we assume the acquisitions happen in the middle of the year.

This results in higher local currency growth of \(0.1\%\) in FY25, \(1.1\%\) in FY26, \(2.1\%\) in FY27 and \(3.3\%\) in FY28 in all 3 (base, bull and bear) scenarios (see [REFERENCE NOT FOUND]). The valuation increases by CHF 23/share in the base case, CHF 21/share in the bear case and CHF 26/share in the bull case.

Answering the primary question on investors' minds: When will Sika return to the mid- single digit local organic growth? Over the last 20 years Sika has seen \(\sim 6\%\) organic growth, however, over the last couple of years, this has fallen to \(\sim 1\%\) . This has been complemented by acquisitions.

In our base case, Sika moves beyond the \(6\%\) organic growth rate by 2027. In the Bull case, Sika reaches \(6\%\) organic growth in 2026, however, in the bear case, Sika remains slightly below the \(6\%\) organic growth rate over the forecast period.

Post, Sika's guidance cut for FY25 at the Q2 results, we have had several investors asking us whether Sika's mid- term local currency growth guidance of \(6 - 9\%\) is at risk. Taking future potential acquisitions in account, in the base case the local currency growth ranges between \(6 - 10\%\) over 2026- 28. In the bull case, the local currency growth is even stronger at \(7 - 11\%\) and in the bear case the local currency growth ranges between \(5 - 9\%\) over the forecast period (see Exhibit 13).
EXHIBIT 13: Assuming bolt-on acquisitions in future already takes LC growth to over \(6\%\) by 2026
Source: Bernstein analysis and estimates

We value Sika at CHF 255/share, implying 36% potential upside (see Exhibit 14). 1% flat increase/decrease in volume growth over 2026- 28 results in a change in valuation of CHF 20 (see Exhibit 15). Similarly, including M&A, increases valuation by CHF 21- 26/share (see Exhibit 16).
EXHIBIT 14: Sika Valuation and Price target

References to "Bernstein" or the "Firm" in these disclosures relate to the following entities: Bernstein Institutional Services LLC (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC (pre April 1, 2024), Bernstein Autonomous LLP, BSG France S.A. (April 1, 2024 onwards), Sanford C. Bernstein (Hong Kong) Limited 盛博香港有限公司, Sanford C. Bernstein (Canada) Limited, Sanford C. Bernstein (India) Private Limited (SEBI registration no. INH00006378), Sanford C. Bernstein (Singapore) Private Limited and Sanford C. Bernstein Japan KK (サンフォード・C・バーンスタイン株式会社).

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

We use a DCF methodology to derive our target price for Sika of CHF255. Our WACC is \(7.6\%\) . We use a risk- free rate of \(2.2\%\) , equity risk premium of \(6.5\%\) , beta of 1.0 and weighted average cost of debt of \(1.3\%\) after tax. We apply a terminal growth of \(3.3\%\) .

Downside risks - 1) Adverse development of macroeconomic and geopolitical factors weakens Sika's volume growth. 2) New break- through solutions/techniques by peers takes market share from Sika. 3) Supply chain disruptions or general raw material inflation which can't be offset through pricing.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
